To determine if we can infer that "Ben ate pasta," we need to examine whether the statement "Ben ate pasta" is a necessary consequence of the two given statements. In this case, the second statement tells us that "Kate ate the salad," which matches the conclusion of the conditional statement. However, this does not necessarily mean that the hypothesis of the conditional statement is true. We are not given any information about whether Ben ate pasta or not.
